title-group.article-title: Perceived body weight, eating and exercise problems of different groups of women

contrib.aff: Research Assistant, Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, University of Sydney, and Northside Clinic and Westmead Hospital, Sydney, NSW, Australia
Psychiatrist and Clinical Lecturer, Department of Psychiatry, University of Sydney, Sydney, NSW, Australia
Associate Professor, Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, Department of Psychological Medicine, University of Sydney, and Northside Clinic, Sydney, NSW, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Associate Professor Suzanne Abraham, E25 Royal North Shore Hospital, The University of Sydney, NSW 2006, Australia Email: suzanne.abraham@sydney.edu.au

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To compare prevalence of problems with body weight, eating and exercise (past or present) of female psychiatric inpatients with routine care, gynaecological and obstetric female outpatients, and eating disorder inpatients.

sec.title: Method:
sec.p: One thousand and thirty-eight females aged 18–55 years from routine care (n=99), gynaecological (n=263) and obstetric (n=271) outpatient clinics, and eating disorder (n=223) and general psychiatric units (n=182) participated. Participants self-reported past or current problems with weight, eating and exercise using a short survey. A sub-sample of women completed the Eating and Exercise Examination (EEE) which includes the Quality of Life for Eating Disorders (QOL ED).

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The prevalence of self-reported problems controlling weight (52%), disordered eating and eating disorders (43%) for the psychiatric patients was significantly greater than for the routine care and gynaecological and obstetrics outpatients. The psychiatric group had a significantly higher mean body mass index (BMI) of 27.3 kg/m2 (standard deviation (SD)=6.7) and prevalence of self-reported obesity (28%) than the other groups.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Treatment of women with psychiatric problems should include assessment and concurrent attention to body weight, eating disorder and exercise problems in association with appropriate medical, psychiatric, psychological and medication treatment of their presenting disorder.

body.p: The overall prevalence of eating disorders in women is on the rise. Eating disorders have one of the highest mortality rates of any psychiatric illness.1,2 Death results not only from the physical impact of the illness but also from accidents, substance misuse and suicide.2,3 This suggests that psychiatric pathology contributes to the high mortality rates in these women.

The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders fourth edition (DSM-IV) Axis I and II disorders have been reported in 80–97% of women with eating disorders.4,5 These disorders not only increase patient mortality but also eating disorder severity, chronicity and treatment resistance.6–8 Concomitant mental health problems may precede, co-exist with, and persist, after the treatment of the eating disorder.

Given the association between eating disorders and other psychiatric pathology, an increased prevalence of eating and exercise problems within the general psychiatric population would be expected .4,5,7,9–12 There is no published research about the prevalence of eating disorders that we should expect to find in this group. Determining eating disorder prevalence and aetiology in female psychiatric inpatients would assist in the management and treatment of both eating disorders and co-existing psychiatric disorders.

The study aimed to determine the self-reported prevalence of eating, exercise and body weight problems in psychiatric patients and in routine care, gynaecological, obstetric and eating disorder patients aged 18–55 years. Comparisons of the prevalence of self-reported problems and of eating disorder subtypes were made between the psychiatric group with the other four comparison groups. We anticipated that the prevalence of eating, exercise and body weight problems would be higher in the psychiatric group compared to the routine care, gynaecological and obstetrics groups. We also expected the prevalence of eating, exercise and body weight problems in the psychiatric group should be lower than in the eating disorder group and that the levels of obesity and eating disorder not otherwise specified (EDNOS) would be higher in the psychiatric group than the eating disorder group due to psychotropic medications and behavioural problems.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Women aged 18–55 years without major physical illnesses influencing their body weight and eating behaviour were asked to participate in this study. Patients with current psychosis were excluded from participating due to the difficulties in obtaining an accurate history.

Patients were invited to participate either by a medically qualified doctor or a research assistant. Contact was made with outpatients during routine clinics or with inpatients. The psychiatric group comprised patients from the CJ Cummins Unit, Royal North Shore Hospital, and the non-eating disorder units at Northside Clinic Greenwich (see Figure 1 for details of specific psychiatric diagnoses). Patients with an eating disorder as their primary diagnosis upon admission were excluded from psychiatric group. The routine care group were attendees of routine clinics (e.g. cervical screening) in the same Northern Sydney Area Health Service. The women in the gynaecological and obstetrics groups were attendees of non-routine gynaecological clinics and routine obstetrics clinics at Royal North Shore Hospital. The patients in the eating disorder group were inpatients of the eating disorder unit at Northside Clinic.

caption.p: Details of the psychiatric group including the hospital to which patients were admitted and the diagnoses for which they were being treated.

sec.title: Questionnaires
sec.p: A short survey was devised for the study. The first section requested the participant’s place of birth, age, height, weight, desired weight, current diagnosis, current medications and past and present psychiatric conditions. The second section contained three questions asking whether the participant had ever suffered, for three months or more, from problems controlling their body weight/problems with disordered eating or an eating disorder/problems with excessive exercise or an exercise disorder. The responses to these three questions were on a five-point Likert scale ranging from ‘not at all’ (0) to ’a lot (4). If any of these questions were answered positively, the participant was then asked to specify the age at which the problem/s occurred and to identify, for the eating and exercise disorder items as appropriate, either the type of eating disorder from a given list of common classifications or whether they felt they had suffered from an excessive exercise disorder. The survey took less than five minutes for people to complete. The three questions were based on items from the Eating and Exercise Examination (EEE).13 The EEE includes the Quality of Life for Eating Disorders (QOL ED) questionnaire which has been validated to assess the impact of eating disorders on both physical and psychological domains.14 A sub-sample of participants completed the EEE in addition to the short survey.

Data collection occurred between December 2008 and February 2011. Refusals were recorded to ensure the proportion did not exceed 10%. The project was approved by the Northern and Central Coast Human Ethics Committee and Northside Clinic Ethics Committee.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Demographic comparisons between the groups were conducted using analysis of variance (ANOVA), followed by pairwise contrasts, with the psychiatric group as the comparison group. This series of ANOVAs explored differences in age, BMI (kg/m2), dissatisfaction with body weight (current BMI minus desired BMI) and time since onset of eating disorder (if reported present).

Chi-square analyses were used to compare the prevalence of self-reported problems with body weight, eating disorders and excessive exercise between the psychiatric group and each of the other four comparison groups. More specifically, presence of a problem was defined as responses of ‘somewhat’ to ‘a lot’ (2 to 4 on the Likert scale). For those patients who identified having a history of an eating disorder (anorexia nervosa (AN), bulimia nervosa (BN), EDNOS, obesity, exercise disorders), comparisons were again conducted between the psychiatric group and the other comparison groups, looking at the distribution of the eating disorder types, using chi-square analyses.

For the sub-sample who completed the EEE in addition to the short survey, comparisons were made between groups on QOL ED scores. The QOL ED has a global score and six sub-scores: body weight, eating behaviour, eating disorder feelings, psychological feelings, effect on daily living (relationships, work/study, social life), and acute medical.14 There are two additional scores not included in the QOL ED global score: overeating feelings and exercise feelings. Two multiple analysis of variances (MANCOVAs) were conducted: the first with the QOL ED global score (minus the body weight component which reflects BMI) and the two additional scores, and the second with the five QOL ED sub-scores (other than body weight). Post hoc multiple comparisons with a Bonferroni correction were applied to examine group differences. For the purposes of these analyses, the obstetric and gynaecology groups were combined.

Partial correlations, with age and BMI as co-variates, examined the association between the short survey questions on history of problems controlling body weight, problems with an eating disorder and problems with excessive exercise and the QOL ED scores. The eating disorder group was excluded from these analyses to prevent artificially inflating associations between the measures.
All statistical analyses were performed using SPSS (IBM, version 19) and alpha was set at 0.05.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The sample included 1038 adult females aged 18–55 years from a major urban centre in Sydney, Australia. Ninety-one percent of the women were Caucasian (n=945), 5% were non-Indian Asian (n=51), 2% were Indian (n=21), and the remaining 2% were South American (n=10), South Pacific Islander or Aboriginal (n=8) and African (n=3).

Age, current BMI, dissatisfaction with body weight (current BMI minus desired BMI) and time since onset of eating disorder (if reported) are presented for the separate groups in Table 1. There was a significant difference in age and current BMI between the psychiatric group and each of the comparison groups.

caption.p: Comparison of the psychiatric group with the other four groups for demographic factors and time since onset of eating disorder.

fn.p: BMI: body mass index; SD: standard deviation.
Dissatisfaction with current weight is current BMI minus desired BMI.
Only includes participants who self-reported problems with disordered eating or an eating disorder as ‘somewhat’, ‘moderately’ or ‘a lot’.

sec.p: Approximately half of the psychiatric group self-reported problems controlling weight, just under half self-reported problems with disordered eating, and less than one in five self-reported problems with disordered exercise (Table 2). These proportions differed significantly from the comparison groups for all except disordered exercise in the routine care group. For those women who reported problems with disordered eating, the prevalence of specific subtypes of eating disorders is presented by group in Table 3. The most common eating disorder in the psychiatric group was obesity (28% of the n=182).

caption.p: Comparison of the prevalence of problems with weight, eating and exercise between the psychiatric group and each of the other four groups (df=1)

fn.p: Self-reported presence of a problem was defined as responses of ‘somewhat’, ‘moderately’ or ‘a lot’.

caption.p: Comparison of the psychiatric group with the four other groups for the prevalence of the eating disorder subtypes (df=1).

fn.p: EDNOS: eating disorder not otherwise specified.

sec.p: Five hundred and sixty-nine women completed the EEE in addition to the short survey. The psychiatric group demonstrated poorer eating disorder related quality of life (higher scores) compared with the routine care and the combined obstetric and gynaecology group, but better eating disorder related quality of life compared with the eating disorder group (Table 4).

caption.p: Mean quality of life for eating disorders (QOL ED) scores by group (N=569).

tr.th: Significant group differences compared with psychiatric

tr.td: QOL ED global minus body weight score

td.bold: Sub-scores not included in global score

fn.p: Higher QOL ED scores indicate poorer eating disorder related quality of life.

sec.p: Partial correlations between the short survey responses and the QOL ED scores accounted for two covariates: age and current BMI. The correlations of the three questions (problems controlling weight, problems with disordered eating, and problems with disordered exercise) with the QOL ED scores are presented in Table 5 for all the women, excluding the eating disorder group. Very high positive correlations were obtained between QOL ED scores and short survey problems with body weight and problems with disordered eating. The strength of the correlations between QOL ED scores with problems with excessive exercise were generally weaker.

caption.p: Partial correlations between the short survey questions and the quality of life for eating disorders (QOL ED) scores, accounting for age and current body mass index (BMI), in the sample excluding the eating disorder group (N=345).

tr.th: Ever had problems with body weight? N=345
Ever had a problem with an eating disorder? N=345
Ever had problems with excessive exercise? N=345

tr.td: QOL ED global minus body weight score

td.bold: Sub-scores not included in global score

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The high prevalence of past or current self-reported eating disorders within our general psychiatric group is consistent with the known relationship between Axis I and II psychiatric disorders and eating disorders.4,5,8,9–12 The mean time since the onset of an eating disorder diagnosis for these psychiatric patients was 21 years. Given the mean age of this group (36 years, standard deviation (SD)=10.7), the average age of onset would be the late teens. Previous studies have shown the average age of eating disorder onset to be between 16–18 years.15,16 This suggests that the age and nature of the eating disorders in the psychiatric population may be comparable to those in the comparison groups.

The psychiatric group reported high levels of AN, BN and EDNOS, corresponding with the increased levels of disordered eating in the psychiatric group. The prevalence of each of these eating disorders was raised significantly above that of the routine care, gynaecology and obstetric groups, suggesting that no sole eating disorder is responsible for the higher rates of disordered eating within this group.

The proportion of patients claiming to have a history of an excessive exercise disorder were not significantly different in the psychiatric group compared to the routine care group. This was unanticipated given that Grave et al. found that, in eating disorder inpatients, almost half compulsively exercised to control their weight or shape.17 Exercise disorders have been shown to be more frequently associated with AN than with BN or EDNOS.17 The absence of an increased number of self-reported exercise disorders in the psychiatric group compared to our routine care group suggests it is possible that eating disorder patients with co-morbid exercise disorders may be less likely to suffer future psychiatric problems or may be less likely to seek help for these problems.

The psychiatric group had higher BMI and reported greater levels of past or current obesity than the other groups. Obesity rates of up to three times that of the normal population have been reported in psychiatric populations.18 This may be attributed to behavioural changes associated with psychiatric disorders, or the medications used in their treatment. Binge or chaotic eating in psychiatric patients may be used as a coping mechanism, or may be a result of increased appetite and decreased inhibition caused by psychiatric drugs.19 Lithium, valproic acid, tricyclic antidepressants and atypical antipsychotics have all been associated with significant weight gain.20,21

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: Any study relying on participants to self-report diagnoses is vulnerable to bias. Participants may self-diagnose incorrectly or may be professionally misdiagnosed. Self-reported problems with controlling weight and with disordered eating and exercise are also highly subjective. Without providing solid criteria, the question of problems with weight control depends heavily on womens’ perceptions of their body shape and weight, and their definition of the word ‘problem’. Greater specificity within the questionnaire may improve the accuracy of these results but would also increase the time of completion, and possibly the response rate, for this survey.

Patterns by which people report their own weight and height have been examined in the literature. There is a strong tendency for most participants to underestimate weight and overestimate height.22,23 In situations of self-reporting, people often choose the more socially acceptable response, aiming to create a more agreeable image of themselves.22,23 In eating disorder sufferers, denial and distortion may impair their ability to report accurately their weight and the extent of their problems.24

The short survey questioned whether women had ‘ever suffered’ from body weight, eating or exercise problems. The way in which this question is phrased prevents us differentiating between patients with current and past eating disorders. The EEE does allow us to make this differentiation. It was only performed in a sub-sample of our groups and unfortunately the proportion of psychiatric patients completing this lengthy assessment was quite low.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Few studies have looked at the prevalence of past or current eating disorders among psychiatric inpatients, despite the significant burden of psychiatric pathology in patients with an eating disorder. Our results suggest that women whose primary diagnosis is psychiatric are more likely to have a history of an eating disorder than those attending non-psychiatric outpatient clinics. Whether the current or past eating disorder has an impact on the treatment of their co-morbid psychopathology is not known. Inadequate nutrition, poor body image and anxiety about weight and shape may exacerbate other psychiatric co-morbidities. Future research should determine the prevalence of current eating disorders within this group and explore the degree to which disordered eating affects psychiatric patients and whether treatment directed at this distinct disease process is warranted.

ack.p: The authors would like to thank Georgina Luscombe for assistance with statistics and editing of this paper.

fn.label: Disclosure
fn.p: The authors report no conflict of interest. The authors alone are responsible for the content and writing of the paper.
